reviews.content: Blind tasting Nose: Fresh, fruity nose. Lots of orange jam. Toffee. Clear bourbon influence. A minimal fermented note in the background. May have also seen a drained sherry cask. Smells like a classic Speysider with some woody notes a la Glenlivet 15. Mouth: Gentle, reserved. Creamy. The bourbon influence remains very dominant. Very clear notes of toffee and caramel play the main role. Only behind this comes a subtle orange fruitiness. Bright, slightly citrusy fruit notes are hidden. He's minimally sweet. More in the spicy oak direction. Develops a stronger bitterness. He saw wood. Finish: Rather short. Unexciting. Malty. Getting drier. Slightly dusty. Nice standard. Easy sipping. Not what would stand out.

Overall this is a quite ok entry malt for beginners. I would not recommend it to any non-beginners. The 40% is a bit low and it lacks complexity, however this could be a great whisky for guests due to it's nice sweet taste. I can't find any citrus here tho as Aberlour states that it's their character of the new distillate, the sherry butts took control of this whisky. 80 / 100

reviews.taste: Dried fruits such as figs and prunes. Dark chocolate balances the sweetness. Leather and some oak. Again a bit too thin, not too oily and definitely could be better.
reviews.finish: Short to medium. Warm nut and sherry aromas with some bitter dark chocolate at the end.

reviews.content: Drifts towards Speyside as it spends time in the glass. Chill-filtered. Coloured. Matured in ex-bourbon American oak casks and in sherry Spanish oak casks. Mid-size slow primary legs. Mid-size very slow secondary legs. Trailing droplets.

Typically Speyside. This label is attached to many bottlings from various distilleries on the banks of the River Spey. This makes it all the more difficult for a beginner in the world of whisky to choose the right one. But what does the right one ultimately mean? It probably means something different for everyone. In my case, I can only say that I didn't go far wrong with my choice, which fell on the Aberlour 12 Double Cask (a marriage of two parallel maturations in bourbon and sherry casks). And that despite the fact that this distillery no longer manages without coloring and (at least with the Double Cask) without chill filtration - and is bottled at just 40% ABV. However, if you are just starting your journey into the world of malts, this might be a good idea. Especially since, in my opinion - many vloggers and experts see it differently (probably due to longer experience) - the Double Cask still brings a certain complexity for a first attempt at nosing and tasting. But let's take a closer look: Aroma: First impression after letting both nostrils circle over the dram: Restrained bouquet, dominated by a nutty spiciness that I would attribute to the wood of the sherry casks. I also think I can detect traces of citrus fruits. A very "light" sweetness, comparable to lemons or star fruit. I don't detect much more on first contact. A second sip is required here, which makes the aroma much stronger and darker straight away. I can now sniff out traces of fig. In any case, the sherry comes through more, but pleasantly, without completely overpowering the whisky. The vanilla typical of bourbon escaped me, at least. Nevertheless - I really like this nose. Taste: Phew, it's so tasty. The sip is velvety, but with a certain heavy, but not overpowering woody spice (maybe I taste ginger here too?) on the tongue and then literally goes down like oil. The 40 percent certainly doesn't give the dram any punch, but it doesn't make it hang in the air or seem too watery. On the contrary: the sweetness is less strong than it did on the nose, but I think I can taste other fruits like peach or apricot and less of the often-cited chocolate. But maybe it's the melting quality with which this Aberlour spreads in the mouth that I find extremely pleasant in any case. My taste buds don't get much more out of this dram. But it's not necessary when it ends up being so tasty and well-rounded. Finish: Medium-long and, as expected, the biggest "weakness" of the Double Cask. Mild, soft and with a little spice, the dram makes its way south without lingering for long. It's not absolutely necessary, as it's so drinkable that you'll already be ready for the next sip. Conclusion: Currently (August 2024), the Aberlour 12 year old Double Cask is available for around 40 euros from various online retailers (unfortunately, it often costs 10 to 20 euros more in stores). That would be another selling point, if the 12 year old Unchillfiltered with 48% ABV wasn't available in some places for even less money. Without knowing the latter (still waiting on the shelf), I would say or recommend that beginners in particular would be better off with the Double Cask to start with. Especially for the autumn and winter, this is a very tasty dram with which you can take your first steps into Speyside relatively carefully. And one of the two 12 year olds from Aberlour will certainly become a standard in my selection in the long run.

It requests a lot of time to become aromatic and sweet. I rather drink non-chil filtered Abelour 12y than it.
Whisky with a stunning rich interesting varied pleasant aroma. Completely devoid of taste.Points purely for the aroma.
Overall, it's a sweet, soft whisky with little depth. The nose is slightly better than the palate and finish; a pleasant, average whisky.
reviews.nose: On the nose, aromas of sweet oak barrel, sweet malt, caramel, vanilla, honey, dried fruits, apple, caramelized brown sugar, dark fruits, very light cherry, sour cherry, and apple jam are perceived.
reviews.taste: On the palate, there are oily, soft, sweet notes of honey, caramel, and malt, a hint of vanilla, dry sugared apple, a very slight hint of peach, and a light and soft white pepper.
reviews.finish: The finish is short to medium in length, neither drying nor moistening the palate; it starts with honey caramel in the middle, then warms slightly with white pepper, and finally leaves a very light taste on the palate reminiscent of slightly dried apple, peach, and caramel.

A truly great entry level whisky, the nose is really nice, but the taste and finish lack complexity. At my local price point this is one of the best bang for your buck out there.

Even on the nose you can tell this is a sweet whisky. The palate is full of caramel, plum and banana, with plenty of sweetness overall. Sherry notes are noticeable, and the finish lingers with honey for a long time. Very tasty, entry level sherry whisky.

It has gotten better after some time in the flask, or I developed a palette more suited for this whisky. It is pretty good. Mild, sweet, it is complex in a very harmonious way. Overal theme is pretty intriguing although straightforward: spices, matured sweets, and some bitternes.
reviews.nose: Some ginger and rosemary. Apple sweetness and a small bit of sourness. dried/sugary/ cooked fruits. Oak but not as striking and dominant as a glenlivet founders edition first fill cask, mostly in the background. a bit of spice maybe cinnamon, black pepper. A bit of dust. Does not smell very floral or does not remind me of fresh fruits. It mostly smells cooked. Probably due to the sherry cask influence.
reviews.taste: Sweet. Alcohol is noticeable but does not make the whisky taste very young. Feels mature. Kind of like a honey sweetness. Red apples, and bitterness of the seeds. It tastes caramelized. Maybe like an apple dessert prepared by cooking the apple in its water with its seeds. Oak, mostly at the end when the others tastes fade away.
reviews.finish: Seed bitterness, spice, oak. Not exciting but not unpleasant.
